newsitem.title: USA: INSIGHT-Dlr/mark end above 1.84 may reassure bulls.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT-Dlr/mark end above 1.84 may reassure bulls.

text.p: A handle on 1.84 marks by Tuesday's close could reestablish the dollar's long term bullish trend recovery and signal another visit to last week's highs above 1.87, technical analysts said.
But it must overcome key resistance first. A retake of last week's 1.8476 and 1.8465 mark highs is needed to refuel the rally, analysts said.
"Anything under 1.8450/1.85 keeps some pressure on the market although it's had a pretty good reversal from Friday's lows," said Greg Troccoli, technical analyst at Prudential Securities.
"It still has a little work to do to get back on its feet," Troccoli added.
Thursday's and Friday's highs are close to a 50 percent retracement of the dollar/mark downmove from 1.8913 on August 6 to the low of 1.8050 on Monday.
A close above 1.8450 would provide a starting point for followthrough dollar/mark gains, said Troccoli, who added that long-term trend damage has been minimal.

Elsewhere, dollar/yen was set to make a one yen move in the near-term, with momentum studies favoring a sharp move higher, according to Ture Johnson, technical analyst at Bank of America. Johnson and other analysts have pegged rates well above 120 yen longer term.
"We're back in the previous trading range before dollar/yen broke down, which was basically 118 to 119.50," Johnson said. "Now we're above 118 so we're back in the previous consolidation area."
A mark/yen rally could fuel the dollar/yen rise, Johnson said, despite the cross's apparent weakness on Tuesday.

That optimism has a narrow window, however. Johnson said a failure to find 119 yen by Wednesday would prompt a more severe selloff as deep as 116.50 or 116.30, the bottom of the current trading range.

Thom Worden, vice president of Deutsche Morgan Grenfell's technical analysis group, said a move back to the high of last Friday, 118.70 yen, could signal a rapid rise to 119.50. But Worden was not so sanguine on the liklihood that that might happen by Wednesday.
"On the downside, if we go through the lows made in early New York near 118.05 that would mean a move to at least the 117.20/30 area," Worden said. "That's the way I'm leaning."
